photos.description: View from the road just below Little Summit. Looking at Blakely Island, Obstruction Pass, and in the far right Lopez Island and Decator Island. (Ken)
TBD

photos.people: Ken Culver, Carroll Culver, Bruce Culver
photos.description: Photo op of large king salmon just before Carroll cut it up for kippering in the smoke house.

One of the earliest photos of the floats all in position with most of the rental boats in the water. There appear to be 2 inboard Reinell boats - one on the buoy, and one at the floats. The other interesting thing is the large open skiff on the outside of the main float. I vaguely remember this boat coming from Bellingham to fish, and believe the owner built it himself. I want to say his name was Vanderford and he often stayed in the little 'trailer house' up behind the Lodge over by the camping area. I was intrigued by this boat as it had an inboard engine and could plane. The owner stood straight up in the middle of the boat and steered with a 'stick' which was connected by ropes and pulleys to the rudder. (Ken)
Ken Culver age 13 on the floats at Pt Lawrence Lodge. (Ken)

Ken Culver wearing his life jacket, which was mandatory to be on the floats or in a boat. My father told me that once I could swim from the buoy (where boats were moored) to shore at high tide with all my clothes on I could take it off. Sometime between 1952 and 1954 I did just that! (Ken)

Another of the Jacobson Studio postcards depicting the Lodge at its prime. Tents to the right of the Lodge - the fee was $1 per night. The main Lodge, cedar log floats, and 16' Reinell cedar planked rental boats. The boat on the right was an inboard - it had a little air cooled Wisconsin engine and a rope/tiller steering system. Top speed was not enough to buck the big incoming tides but it was quiet and burned next to no gas. Note the garage building just to the left of the Lodge. You can also see tents pitched to the right of the Lodge, which is now State Park land. (Ken)

Building on the far right was Vanderford's 'Trailer House'. It was eventually left on the property. I am baffled by the 'house' like structure on the far left of this photo. This was at best a 'tent frame' when I was a child. The final cabin #12 was built here around 1950 and still stands on the site. The overhead ramp to the Lodge had not been constructed yet, and the boat launch had changed to a marine railway that came off the main boathouse platform. My guess is that this, as well as the earlier overhead boat launch did not fair well in winter storms. Also the elevation of the boathouse made it too steep and required lots of maneuvering to position a boat for launch. Ultimately the area down by the smoke house became the 'lower platform' with a hand cranked winch marine rail way to launch and retrieve boats. (Ken)

Jolly Old St. Nicholas (Carroll Culver with his sack of toys over his back.) He enjoyed an opportunity to ham it up. No idea what the actual occasion was but I do remember women dressing like this for pot-lucks and square dancing - usually at Doe Bay, or the Olga Clubhouse, or sometimes at the dining room at Pt Lawrence. (Ken)
Looking West out of Obstruction Pass. Obstruction Island on the left with Lopez Island in background. (Ken)

photos.location: Photo taken from Mt. Constitution, Orcas Island of Mt. Baker and Bellingham. Lummi Island in the foreground - Lego Bay just left of center in the image. Pt. Francis (part of the Lummi Indian reservation) behind Lummi separated by Hales Pass.
photos.description: TBD

Cabin 4. 1950s vehicles. Carrol lived in this building before building other cabins. He expanded this building out over time. Pacific Telephone and Telegraph ('Pacific Tel & Tel') lines and poles are visible on the hill in the background. Lines went under water at 'the second beach' and crossed Rosario Straits to Lummi Island. There was a large Cable Crossing sign erected at Pt Lawrence itself to warn mariners not to anchor (not that any one in their right mind would consider it, given the exposure and fierce tide rips). (Ken)

Holiday card. Whoever took this photo must have done so very soon after the snow fall, as there was virtually no insulation in the Lodge and snow melted off of it quickly. Of Note: There is a post on the little point at the far right of the photo. This was a fence post with 'sheep fence wire' running up into the woods behind the camping area and outhouses. Its purpose was to prevent the sheep that Carroll was raising from getting down onto the beach and onto the property (which guests loved and he hated), as they are basically stupid animals that are very challenging to herd. The sheep had free reign of all the land down to the Point and up the North Shore. When it was time to shear them for their wool the flock had to be located and then driven all the way back to the barn at Alderwood. This often took most of a day, and a number of people, since we had no sheep dogs. Occasionally the lead sheep would bolt and double back and the whole flock would follow. (Ken)
Big Chris-Craft boat. Owner was a guest at the resort named 'McDonald' from Seattle. Floating bait box visible at the end of the float on far right of photo.

photos.location: Point Lawrence Lodge - the large float
photos.description: Ken Culver water skiing off of end of float on water skis he and Dwight Reed handmade. Bruce Culver to his right. Harry Reed who owned Twin Cedars resort at Doe Bay called Bruce 'burr-head' because of his close-cropped haircut.
